description: 17th c., perhaps from Low German or Dutch pal (“catch (mechanism)”), or from either French pal (“stake”) or épaule (“shoulder”).

entries.meaning: A pivoted catch designed to fall into a notch on a ratchet wheel so as to allow movement in only one direction (e.g. on a windlass or in a clock mechanism), or alternatively to move the wheel in one direction.
examples: The nails in the rim of the wheel went ratcheting over the leather pawl and the wheel slowed and came to a stop and the woman turned to the crowd and smiled.

entries.meaning: A similar device to prevent motion in other mechanisms besides ratchets.

verbs.description: pawl (third-person singular simple present pawls, present participle pawling, simple past and past participle pawled)
